Authors:
Subodini Nuwanthika Wijesinghe, Monika Chandani Dayarathne,
Sajeewa S.N. Maharachchikumbura, Dhanushka Nadeeshan Wanasinghe, Kevin D
Hyde
Title:
Ceramothyrium chiangraiense, a novel species of
Chaetothyriales (Eurotiomycetes) from Ficus sp. in Thailand
Keywords: new species, epifoliar fungi, morphology, phylogeny
Abstract:
In our investigation of epifoliar fungi, a novel species
of Ceramothyrium; C. chiangraiense is isolated from the living leaves of
Ficus sp. in Thailand. Genus Ceramothyrium is characterized by the
ascomata cover with pellicle mycelium and the circumferential space
around the maturing ascomata, lack of seatae, olivaceous to fuscous and
hyaline to subhyaline or straw-coloured hyphae and hyaline, transversely
pluriseptate (phragmospores) ascospores. The new species resembles genus
Ceramothyrium by its ascomata with superficial mycelial pellicle over
the fruiting structures and scattered ascomata that cupulate when dry ,
8 spored bitunicate asci which contain hyaline, pluriseptate ascospores.
We have processed the phylogenetic analyses with combined ITS and LSU
sequence data based on Maximum Likelihood (ML) and Bayesian (BI)
analyses. Based on phylogeny Ceramothyrium chiangraiense is confirmed
its placement within the genus Ceramothyrium and closely related to C.
aquaticum, C. carniolicum, C. exiguum, C. linnaeae and C. phuquocense.
Morphologically, Ceramothyrium chiangraiense is distinguished from those
species by the characteristics of size of ascomata, shape and size of
asci and arrangement, sepatation and lacking of the mucronate
ascospores. The relationship of C. chiangraiense with other
Ceramothyrium species are discussed based on comparative morphology and
phylogenetic analysis to confirm the novel taxonomic placement.
